qas.question: Sumerians used number systems which included what alternating bases?
What type of number system was standard in Sumer and Babylonia?
What type of formations is it possible Sumerians invented?
What systems did the Sumerians develop which remain the first known these types to this day?
In Sumerian society, who oversaw the operation of the first formal schools?
What system did Sumerians borrow from Babylonia?
What was being used for private purposes well before the 26th century BC?
What learning centers were established the temples?

context: They invented and developed arithmetic by using several different number systems including a mixed radix system with an alternating <a0_0>base 10 and base 6<a0_0/>. This <a1_0><b5_0>sexagesimal<a1_0/> system<b5_0/> became the standard number system in <b8_0>Sumer<b8_0/> and Babylonia. They may have invented <a2_0>military<a2_0/> formations and introduced the basic divisions between infantry, cavalry, and archers. They developed the first known codified <a3_0>legal and administrative<a3_0/> systems, complete with courts, jails, and government records. The first true city-states arose in Sumer, roughly contemporaneously with similar entities in what are now Syria and Lebanon. Several centuries after the invention of cuneiform, the use of <b6_0>writing<b6_0/> expanded beyond debt/payment certificates and inventory lists to be applied for the first time, about 2600 BC, to messages and mail delivery, history, legend, mathematics, astronomical records, and other pursuits. Conjointly with the spread of writing, the first <b7_0>formal schools<b7_0/> were established, usually under the auspices of <a4_0>a city-state's primary temple<a4_0/>.
